data.text: fuji xt20 - small, great lens options, really great customizable workflow... if you have difficulty editing-sharing, shooting jpeg with the recipes really helpd me to commit to an exposure/aesthetic and just move on with my life in the same way youd pick a film stock and just deal with it. more RAW shooting option with those settings as well if you want to shoot RAW ill usually leave on the 27mm pancake as my mainstay, and the 35 1.4 for nighttime, portrait, indoor, or more "serious" shots. the 27(42 equiv) may not be the fastest, sharpest, or have the most bokeh/vibe, but goddang is it a great middleground for all around shooting. closer than 35 which i find often has too much background, and wider than a 50 for those moments when im shooting kinda messy/sloppy from the saddle. the 35(56 equiv) is a little narrow for some situations, but just total magic.

data.text: Honestly, anything you can keep well protected from condensation and isn't some crappy knock off point and click is workable. I took a Canon Rebel XSI my last two tours and it worked well but it also added to weight (not counting the laptop I carried with me for editing/uploading). I'm taking a different DSLR this upcoming coast to coast ride in the US and will also be carrying a tripod, a few lenses, etc. Outside of that, I just used a cheap Tracphone to take stills/video for quick social media updates. It just depends on what you can afford and what you're willing/able to carry. If anything, I'd recommend something that can get you solid close up shots that breach "macro" level while also being able to get wide angle landscape photos.

data.text: I've only used a phone on my bikepacking trips. That being said, I did do a cross country trip on my motorcycle. The first time I took my phone and my wife's fancy Nikon DSLR camera. While the Nikon took excellent pictures as expected, I found it to be a real pain to fish it out of the bag, set it up, use it, and then stow it away again. Whereas if I used my phone I just had to grab it off my handlebars. When I took another motorcycle trip from ATL to AK I decided I'd just buy a new phone and only use it. It was much easier to use, and the quality of the photos is amazing. I've received numerous compliments on the pictures I took, and everyone has asked what kind of camera I used. The fact is, the quality of phone cameras now sometimes outperforms some of the cheaper DSLR's or hand-held's. As a weight saving measure, I think the phone would be the optimal choice. Also, Quadlock sells accessories so you can attach a tripod mount onto the Quadlock phone case. With that you can use it to attach it to a small flexible tripod, or a larger sturdier one. Ultimately, you have to decide what you're going to do with the pictures/video. Is it for you, and friends? Something you'll post on FB. Or are you looking to make a big video production for YouTube, or an article in National Geographic? If it's just for you and friends, I'd say go with a phone and a GoPro. If it's for a big to-do, go all out and get the DSLR. Most importantly though, have fun and enjoy your trip!

data.text: the files on a cell phone are over processed and really only suited for social media and small prints... But, I assume thats all most people are using cameras for anymore. I personally shoot to print my images whether through sales or for personal use, so im a bit more discerning. One issue with cell phones is there is no overhead to process the photos. They always look over processed like a early 2000s camera before you even begin working on them. With an SLR/ILC or advanced compact you have tons of overhead. Probably not something most people care about, and not something you'll notice until you go to crop in on that shot or go to print it big but it is an issue.

data.text: I think two things are important 1) the intended use of the photos Facebook, Instagram, YouTube; social media. Or do you plan to edit and print them? If it's the later than put a pin in it to 2) ease of use/storage/time to create. How much effort you want to put into image creation. If creating content is not really your goal, you just want social media and memories, a cell phone and a gopro is what you need. If content creation and files you edit and print or view at high resolution is what you want then a bigger more serious camera like a compact or ILC is the correct camera. Cell phones are great for low res output but don't scale up well and don't edit well because the images are already highly processed unless you shoot raw and the raw files are honestly not amazing. There are no right or wrong choices. Only what you are willing to carry and deal with. Any brand still producing cameras from Olympus to Sony to Fuji to Canon to Ricoh to Pentax can produce saleable images. If your bikepacking I'd likely opt for something with a M4/3 or APS-C format like Olympus or Fuji since, Imo, it hits the sweet spot of size/form factor and iq for bikepacking. For bike touring you could go with bigger systems like Canon, Pentax or Nikon or Sony. Advantages of Pentax, Fuji, and Olympus are their systems offer high levels of weather sealing on many models, including kit cameras/lenses.
